overview.about-body: As my skills develope I find I am never satisfied with my previous work. Last years portfolio website had stylesheets that were a mess, html that was difficult to read and the site completely fell apart on mobile. I set out this year to create a responsive website that had a clear seperation of concerns and was composed of reusable modules. A big priority was to make easy to make future updates to the site

stack.sub-title: The first step was deciding what web tehnologies would be appropriate to help me acheive my goals

item.title: Bootstrap
item.description: Knowing that I wanted to build a responsive website I chose to use Bootstrap as a CSS framework. It was a good starting point but I eneded up not needing most of it’s features

item.title: SASS
item.description: SASS allowed me to keep my styles nice and tidy throughout the process.

item.title: Assemble
item.description: A static site generator that allowed me to create reusable modules and led the path to a clear seperation of concerns. I kept my data in json files, structure in handlebars files, and reusable components in partials.

item.title: Grunt
item.description: For task management. Allowed me to compile my sass, Assemble static pages and concat and minify my scripts with a simple command.

item.title: Travis CI
item.description: A continous integration service that syncs with github. It detects when I’ve made a commit to the production branch and then builds and deploys to amazon s3.

testing.body: I used Google Page speed to figure out what parts of the site were impacting performance the most.
